historicalDescription: A narrow street in the San Polo sestiere, known for its proximity to the Rialto Contract and the Grand Canal. The area was a bustling center of commerce in the 15th century.

canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named after the adjacent Calle de la Testa (Street of the Head), this dock would have been the main water landing for the neighborhood. The name likely refers to a shop sign or family emblem featuring a head that was once prominent in the area.

This dock served the hatmakers' workshops that were historically concentrated near Calle de la Testa. Venice was known for its millinery trade, and this fondamenta would have been used to receive raw materials and ship finished hats throughout the Mediterranean.

Located near the traditional workshops of Venice's famous mask makers, this dock would have been crucial for the carnival trade. Artisans would receive materials and ship their elaborate masks from this landing, particularly important given Venice's renowned carnival traditions.

Named after the nearby Church of San Canzian, this dock would have served both the church and surrounding parish. The church dates to medieval times and was an important religious center in this district of Venice, making its namesake dock significant for local commerce.

This dock served the textile workers who operated spinning wheels (filatoi) in workshops near Calle de la Testa. Venice's textile industry was vital to its economy during the Renaissance, and this dock would have been used to transport raw silk and cotton as well as finished threads.

connection.historicalDescription: Named after the hatmakers' guild that had several workshops near Calle de la Testa, which itself means 'Street of the Head' - a reference to the hatmaking trade that flourished in this area during the Renaissance period.

Referenced a once-prominent shop sign featuring a gilded head that served as a landmark in Calle de la Testa. Such decorative signs were common in Renaissance Venice to identify businesses in an era when many were illiterate.

Named for the craftsmen who specialized in making berets and caps, who had established their workshops in this area near Calle de la Testa. The 'baretteri' formed an important subset of the larger hatmaking industry in Venice.

Named after the mullet fish that was commonly sold by fishmongers who operated near the bridge. The area connecting to Calle de la Testa was known for small fish contracts that served the local neighborhood.

Named for a noble Venetian family that owned a palazzo near this bridge in the vicinity of Calle de la Testa. Many bridges in Venice were named after prominent families who lived or owned property nearby.

References the mask-makers who had workshops near Calle de la Testa, crafting elaborate masks for the famous Venetian carnivals. Mask-making was a prestigious craft in Renaissance Venice, closely related to theatrical traditions.

Named for the wigmakers who practiced their craft in this area adjacent to Calle de la Testa. During the Renaissance, wigs became fashionable among Venetian nobility, creating a specialized trade that complemented the hatmaking businesses in the area.

Named for the tailors and fabric cutters who worked in the area, using scissors as their primary tool. This bridge connected Calle de la Testa to an area known for textile work and clothing production in Renaissance Venice.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the wood carving artisans who had workshops in this area during the 15th-16th centuries. These craftsmen were known for their detailed ornamental work on furniture and architectural elements found in Venetian palazzi.

Named after a stone relief of the Lion of St. Mark wearing a crown that was displayed in this covered passageway. Near Calle de la Testa, this symbol represented Venetian authority and pride in the Republic.

This former canal was filled in during the 16th century. The name refers to mask makers who had workshops here, supplying masks for Venetian Carnival and theatrical performances, which were popular entertainments in Renaissance Venice.

Named after the velvet textile manufacturers who operated in this area. Venetian velvet was highly prized throughout Europe during the Renaissance, and this street housed workshops where premium velvets were produced.

Named after a notable hat maker's shop that existed here during the 16th century. Located near Calle de la Testa (which references 'head'), this complementary street name referred to the craftsman who made headwear for Venetian nobles.

Named for the public water cistern that was located in this small square. These cisterns were vital infrastructure in Renaissance Venice for collecting and filtering rainwater, as the city had no natural freshwater sources.

This commercial street was home to sellers of Venetian lace, a luxury item produced primarily on the island of Burano. The fine needlework was renowned throughout Europe and was an important export of the Venetian Republic.

Named after the noble Pisani family who owned property in this area during the Renaissance. The Pisani were a prominent nobili family who produced several important figures in Venetian politics and military affairs.

Named after craftsmen who made official seals used by the Venetian government and noble families to authenticate documents. Located near Calle de la Testa, these artisans created intricate images in metal that represented authority and lineage.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Paved Street of the Byzantine Merchants
buildingPoints.streetDescription: One of the first paved streets in this area, named for the Byzantine merchants who conducted trade here. Venice maintained strong commercial ties with Constantinople/Byzantium throughout much of its history.

This covered passageway housed shops selling exotic scents and perfumes. Venice was a major importer of spices, resins, and aromatic substances from the East, which perfumers used to create luxury scented products for noble clientele.

A former canal that was filled in, possibly named after the sign of a tavern or shop displaying a fox, or after the nickname of a local character. Animal symbolism was common in Venetian street naming conventions.

Named for a portrait painter who had a studio here during the 16th century. Being near Calle de la Testa (referring to 'head'), this street likely housed artists who specialized in painting portraits of Venetian nobles and wealthy merchants.

This canalside walkway was named for the foreign ambassadors who may have resided in buildings along this stretch. Venice hosted diplomatic representatives from many nations during its height as a maritime power.

This street, located near Calle de la Testa, was home to artisans who crafted wigs, which became fashionable in Venice during the later Renaissance period. These specialized craftsmen served the Venetian elite who followed European fashion trends.

Named after the candlemakers who operated in this small square. Candle production was an important craft in Renaissance Venice, as quality beeswax and tallow candles were essential for lighting in homes, churches, and palaces.

Named after the noble Malipiero family who owned property surrounding this courtyard. The Malipiero were an ancient Venetian nobili family who contributed several doges and military commanders to the Republic's history.

This commercial street housed craftsmen who worked with Mediterranean coral to create jewelry and decorative items. Coral was highly valued in Renaissance Venice and was crafted into luxury goods for both domestic use and export.

Named after an exotic pet monkey kept by a wealthy merchant or perhaps the sign of a shop or tavern. Exotic animals were sometimes brought to Venice through its extensive trade networks and became symbols for businesses or streets.

Named for the artists who specialized in manuscript illumination and miniature painting. These highly skilled artisans created detailed decorations for books, official documents, and small portraits, catering to wealthy patrons and the Venetian government.
